content.title: Conduit Selection for Infrainguinal Bypass
content.description: Decision-making algorithm for selecting bypass graft conduit material for lower extremity revascularization.
content.definition: Conduit selection for infrainguinal bypass prioritizes autologous vein (great saphenous vein preferred) due to superior patency, especially for below-knee targets. When adequate vein is unavailable, alternative autologous veins or prosthetic grafts may be considered based on outflow target and expected patency.

conduit_hierarchy: 1. Ipsilateral great saphenous vein (in situ or reversed)
6. Prosthetic (PTFE or Dacron) - above knee only preferred
vein_assessment: Assess for prior phlebitis, sclerotic segments
Map entire course from ankle to groin
Evaluate arm veins if leg veins inadequate
prosthetic_considerations: Poor long-term patency for below-knee targets
May use with venous cuff/patch at distal anastomosis
Higher infection risk than autologous vein
special_situations: Arm vein bypass: Cephalic or basilic vein
Distal origin bypass: Shortened bypass from patent popliteal

clinical_pearls: Single-segment GSV is gold standard for all infrainguinal bypass
Arm vein can provide excellent conduit when leg veins depleted
Prosthetic to tibial target: Generally avoid (30% 2-year patency)
Miller cuff/Taylor patch may improve prosthetic distal anastomosis
